items.title: America’s Carbon Markets The Only Way is up. Or is it
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/939067488?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="America’s Carbon Markets The Only Way is up. Or is it"></iframe>
items.description:
US carbon markets surged in 2023, reaching record-high prices, with new markets emerging and existing ones achieving unprecedented levels. BloombergNEF forecasts a potential price of $93 per metric ton for California carbon permits in 2030, prompting industries and investors to gear up for a price rally. What developments are unfolding in American carbon markets, and what can be anticipated next? Where does value lie within American carbon markets, and how can industries and investors leverage opportunities? Is there a trend of consolidation or divergence in compliance and voluntary markets?

John Holl, President of North American Carbon & President of Environmental Trading, Clearsky Advisors
Éric Lachance, Chief Executive Officer, Energir
Daniel Scarborough, Co-founder, President & Chief Operating Officer, IncubEx
Rachel Walsh, Environmental Commodities Strategist, BMO Capital Markets
Moderated by  Bo Qin, Lead Carbon Analyst, BloombergNEF

items.title: Policy Dialogue | Global Decarbonization, Climate Change and Brazil's Historic Opportunity
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/939078328?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Policy Dialogue | Global Decarbonization, Climate Change and Brazil's Historic Opportunity"></iframe>
items.description:
The spotlight of the low carbon transition is on Brazil. As this year’s G-20 President and the host of COP30 in 2025, Brazil faces an historic opportunity to lead the global transition to a low-carbon economy.

The country has laid out an ambitious climate agenda and as demand for renewable energy technologies, green commodities, carbon credits and critical minerals soars, few countries stand to gain−or lose−as much as Brazil.

In this one-on-one with Brazil's National Development Bank's Director of Infrastructure, Energy Transition and Climate Change, Luciana Costa, we will explore how Brazil can leverage its competitive advantages and natural resources to generate economic opportunities across diverse sectors.

Luciana Costa, Director of Infrastructure, Energy Transition and Climate Change, BNDES

Moderated by James Ellis, Latin America Head of Research, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Talk: The Energy Transition: Think Fast and Slow
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/938152666?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Talk: The Energy Transition: Think Fast and Slow"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit New York, 16 - 17 April, 2024

Jon Moore, Chief Executive Officer, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Talk: How Big is a Billion Tons
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/938232710?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Talk: How Big is a Billion Tons"></iframe>
items.description:
It's undeniable that engineered carbon removal technologies like direct air capture (DAC) will play a critical role in helping countries and companies meet their net-zero goals. But, today's extremely high costs and insufficient market regulation are preventing the industry from scaling fast enough to meet the growing demand from corporate buyers. This talk will address how the industry can enable a dramatic scale up of DAC.

Presented by Brenna Casey, Carbon Capture Analyst, BNEF

items.title: Climate Risk Moves Up
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/938211390?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Climate Risk Moves Up"></iframe>
items.description:
Escalating extreme climate events and stricter regulations have prompted many financial institutions to recalibrate their approach to climate risk. This includes quantifying risk exposures, evaluating financial materiality and modeling the future impacts of both physical and transition risks on their portfolios. During this session, experts and industry leaders will discuss their evolving approaches to climate risks, how it is affecting their own business, and how it can ultimately impact the corporations whose exposure to physical and transition risk is being weighed.

Matt Goldklang, Climate Scientist, Man Numeric
Rakhi Kumar, SVP Climate and Sustainability Solutions, Liberty Mutual 
Adam Goehner, Director, ESG Strategy and Risk, British Columbia Investment Mgmt

Moderated by Danya Liu, Climate Risk Senior Associate, BNEF

items.title: Southeast Asia Carbon Market Outlook 2024
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/929820360?app_id=122963" width="426" height="232" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Southeast Asia Carbon Market Outlook 2024"></iframe>
items.description: Held on March 28, 2024, this webinar discussed the year ahead for carbon markets. It was co-hosted by the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KADIN), ASEAN Alliance on Carbon Markets and BloombergNEF, with support from ASEAN-BAC and Equatorise Advisory.

items.title: Beyond Baby Steps: Maritime Shipping’s Path to Lower Emissions
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/910805163?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Beyond Baby Steps: Maritime Shipping’s Path to Lower Emissions"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit San Francisco, January 30 - 31, 2024

Despite a collective agreement to decarbonize, the shipping sector has yet to pick a winning technology. Green ammonia, blue ammonia and methanol are all on the table. But can port infrastructure sustain more than one new fuel? What impact will decarbonization have –not just on shipping costs but also on trade routes and geopolitics? And what role might digital and communication technologies, sails and mode switching play in this sector-wide shift?

Stephan Cizmar, Operating Partner, Blackhorn Ventures
Wisnu M. Santoso, Senior Vice President of Business Development, PT Pertamina (Persero)
Hamish Norton, President, Star Bulk
Anoop Singh, Global Head - Shipping Research, Oil Brokerage

Moderated by Mohith Velamala, Senior Associate, Oil & Shipping, BloombergNEF

items.title: Policy Dialogue: Global Energy Transition The Experience and The Insight
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/892192382?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Policy Dialogue: Global Energy Transition The Experience and The Insight"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Shanghai, 27 - 28 November, 2023


Hao Jiang, Director of International Business Department, China Renewable Energy Engineering Institute
Moderated by Nannan Kou, Head of China Research, BloombergNEF

items.title: Will China’s Carbon Market Take Off Next Year?
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/890939239?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Will China’s Carbon Market Take Off Next Year?"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Shanghai, 27 - 28 November, 2023

China's carbon market had seemed quiet, until uncertainties arose. Carbon price climbed almost 30% in less than two months. It is already in its second compliance cycle. Currently, China has been relatively generous in allocating carbon emission allowances to the market, but there is uncertainty about whether the government will tighten these allowances in the next cycle as it seems to reduce carbon emissions. Expectations for new guidelines and policies in the upcoming compliance cycle raise questions about potential changes, particularly regarding whether there will be distinct benchmarks for emission allowance issuances in different years. Also, when will China Certified Emission Reductions (CCER) issuance be resumed, and how will the additional carbon emission credit supply impact the market? Will China enroll a new industry into the national market, and if so when will that happen?

- Xuan Du, Program Director, Low Carbon Economic Growth, Energy Foundation
- Yan Tong, Executive Director, Senior Trade Manager of Carbon Finance Business, GuotaiJunan Securities Co., Ltd
- Peng Zhang, Industrial and Finance Research Institute, Director of Energy Transition Research Center, Great Wall Securities (China Huaneng Group)
- Yucheng Zhao, Head, Carbon Asset Management Center, China Metallurgical Industry Planning and Research Institute
Moderated by Tianyi Zhao, China Energy Transition Analyst, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Talk: Tripling Global Renewables by 2030
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/890731982?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Talk: Tripling Global Renewables by 2030"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Shanghai, 27 - 28 November, 2023


International leaders are coalescing around a goal of tripling global renewables capacity by 2030, and this ambition looks set to be a core pillar of discussions at COP28. But what are the merits of this goal? How hard will it be to achieve? And which countries have the biggest mountain to climb? This talk will use BNEF's latest data to explore the implications of this goal, as leaders prepare for this year's climate talks in Dubai.

Albert Cheung, Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Head of Global Transition Analysis, BloombergNEF

items.title: Assessing Energy Transition Investment in Emerging Economies: When and What Risk-Adjusted Return?
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/875126221?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Assessing Energy Transition Investment in Emerging Economies: When and What Risk-Adjusted Return?"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit London, October 10 - 11, 2023

Emerging markets and developing economies account for nearly half of total global greenhouse gas emissions and over a third of energy-related emissions. A number of the largest face the challenge of a market structure that strongly favors coal, while private sector-backed cleaner, cheaper alternatives struggle to gain a foothold. National governments, international partners and investors are inching their way towards potential solutions, opening these markets up to both domestic and foreign clean energy investors. This includes the likes of Just Energy Transition Partnerships and conditional debt restructuring from the International Monetary Fund. For many players, their approach to emerging and developing economies will remain to wait and see. But for those able to spend time on potential growth markets, when might there be a pay-off? What is the most likely shape of the opportunity in the coming five years and who stands to benefit? What are the indicators that might signal real progress?

Joaquim Levy, Director of Economic Strategy and Market Relations, Banco Safra (Former Managing Director and Chief Financial Officer, World Bank Group; former Minister of Finance, Brazil; former President, BNDES, 
Anmay Dittman, Co-Head of the Climate Finance Partnership, Blackrock 
Nakul Zaveri, Partner, Leapfrog Investments 

Moderated by Luiza Demoro, Head of Energy Transitions, BloombergNEF

items.title: Executive Dialogue: Ensuring a ‘Just’ Energy Transition: Working with Africa on the Race to Net-Zero
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/875122882?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Executive Dialogue: Ensuring a ‘Just’ Energy Transition: Working with Africa on the Race to Net-Zero"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit London, October 10 - 11, 2023
The global energy transition needs to be fair and just, but it remains unclear what an equitable shift to net zero looks like. Should we convince African nations to keep their oil in the ground instead of extracting it and reaping the economic benefits? Where should Europe source its liquefied natural gas from? Would financing LNG in Africa be consistent with energy transition financing? Is there an ideal balance between energy security, sustainability and affordability that the oil and gas sector can shape?

Andy Inglis, CEO, Kosmos Energy 
Interviewed by David Doherty, Head of Oil and Renewable Fuels Research, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Debate: Should the Offset Market Pivot Towards Technology-Based Removals?
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/874758450?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Debate: Should the Offset Market Pivot Towards Technology-Based Removals?"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit London, October 10 - 11, 2023

The voluntary carbon offset market walked before it could crawl, with many arguing that it has prioritized quantity over quality. The market is oversupplied with a glut of energy and nature-based credits, some of which have been revealed to be low quality. As a result, while companies continue to buy carbon offsets to meet their emission reduction targets, they are faced with scrutiny about the quality of those credits. Recently, companies are signing multi-million-dollar deals for technology-based removal credits. Should the market abandon all existing credits and focus exclusively on new technology-based removal solutions? Are those solutions the offsets market's saving grace, or simply a cog in a much larger machine?

Mark Daly, Head of Technology and Innovation, BloombergNEF
Layla Khanfar, Sustainability Analyst, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Talk: India’s Role in the Transition to a Global Net Zero Economy
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/859701855?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Talk: India’s Role in the Transition to a Global Net Zero Economy"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit New Delhi, Thursday 24 August, 2023

BloombergNEF today launches the New Energy Outlook: India. The report explores India’s energy transition pathways based on two scenarios: Economic Transition Scenario and Net Zero Scenario. Using these scenarios, the report explores the implications for India’s power, industry, transport, and buildings sectors, and charts out the investments and policies needed to help India achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.


Ali Izadi Najafabadi
Head of APAC, BloombergNEF

items.title: If You Build CO2 Transport and Storage, Emitters Will Come Europe’s CCS Incentive Plan
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/837904919?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="If You Build CO2 Transport and Storage, Emitters Will Come Europe’s CCS Incentive Plan"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Munich, June 13th, 2023


If You Build CO2 Transport and Storage, Emitters Will Come: Europe’s CCS Incentive Plan
European governments have poured billions of dollars into offshore CO2 transport and storage networks, hoping this will entice individual emitters to install carbon-capture equipment. The continent is also home to the world’s first carbon mineralization project, a new form of onshore storage that could allay some of the concerns around leaking wells. But will readily available storage be enough to convince the power and industrial sectors to back CCS without a direct subsidy? While Germany has made moves to relax its bans on CO2 storage domestically, many countries are prioritizing hydrogen development. How do the costs and risks of offshore transport and storage compare to onshore? And now that governments have made the first investment, how will the private sector finance the rest?


Alex Bell, Chief Growth Officer, Removr 
Martijn van de Sande, Coordinator CCUS, RVO 
Ulrika Wising, SVP Energy Transition, Exec committee, Vallourec 
Moderated by Sharon Mustri, Analyst, Sustainable Materials, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Talk: The Low-Carbon Industrial Transition Progress, Not Perfection
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/837658496?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Talk: The Low-Carbon Industrial Transition Progress, Not Perfection"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Munich, June 13th, 2023

The low-carbon industrial transition is well underway, with momentum building around the decarbonization of hard-to-abate industries, as well as the development of new industries to supply the batteries, electrolyzers and other technologies for the race to net zero. But an increasingly complex global picture is throwing up new challenges, and it is now more important than ever to seek progress, not perfection.

Albert Cheung, Deputy CEO, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Debate: Can Europes Carbon Market Decarbonize Industry?
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/836585740?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Debate: Can Europes Carbon Market Decarbonize Industry?"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Munich, June 13th, 2023



As Europe makes progress in cleaning up its power system, the focus is shifting to decarbonizing its industries. While the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) drove coal-to-gas switching in the power sector, its role in decarbonizing heavy industry is less obvious. Europe's industrial sector is facing soaring energy costs, carbon leakage risks and declining competitiveness, and has effectively lobbied for significant free allocations. With these challenges ahead, will the world's largest carbon market be enough to push European industry to net-zero?

Mariko O’Neil, Carbon Analyst, BloombergNEF 
Eva Marina Gonzalez Isla, Modelling, BloombergNEF

items.title: Carbon Offset Markets Aberration or Sign of Things to Come
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/826158609?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Carbon Offset Markets Aberration or Sign of Things to Come"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit New York, April 24th-25th, 2023


The past year was a rough year for voluntary carbon offset markets, which shrank in overall value off the back of waning consumer and investor confidence. Futures prices subsequently fell and little progress was made in discussions at COP27 around a global carbon market outlined as part of Article 6. It is not all doom and gloom, however. With more rigorous definitions around quality and greater emphasis on carbon removal, BloombergNEF thinks the offset market could be valued at nearly $1 trillion in 2037. What else is needed to correct the course in the voluntary carbon market and re-instill confidence in buyers and sellers? Can inspiration be taken from other commodity markets?

David Antonioli, CEO, Verra 
Andy Bose, Senior VP, Market Development & Policy, Xpansiv
Shahira Esmail, Managing Director, Sustainability, Global Markets, BMO Radicle 
Moderated by Kyle Harrison, Head of Sustainability Research, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Summit: BNEF Talk: Clean Energy Opportunities in Developing Nations
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/822089815?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Summit: BNEF Talk: Clean Energy Opportunities in Developing Nations"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit New York, April 24th-25th, 2023

Emerging markets and developing economies (EM&DEs) account for nearly half of the total global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and over a third of energy-related emissions. However, the volume of capital currently being deployed to transition these countries to lower-carbon sources of energy is insufficient given the size of the climate challenge. Getting on track is possible, but will require unprecedented collaboration between stakeholders – including policy makers, development financiers and private investors – to build durable enabling frameworks within nations. Extraordinary declines in zero-carbon technology costs and key successes in certain EM&DE’s highlight how quickly successes can come under the right circumstances. When the right players work together in the right ways, change can come very quickly.

Luiza Demôro
Head of Energy Transitions, BloombergNEF

items.title: Introducing the Carbon Centre of Excellence - B20 Legacy Program
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/769676464?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Introducing the Carbon Centre of Excellence - B20 Legacy Program"></iframe>
items.description: Introduction to B20 Indonesia's Legacy Program to promote carbon markets as a tool for driving decarbonization.

items.title: BloombergNEF on Carbon Markets
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/766879438?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BloombergNEF on Carbon Markets"></iframe>

items.title: BNEF Summit: When Will Carbon Markets and Carbon Borders Drive the Industrial Decarbonization
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/715142990?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Summit: When Will Carbon Markets and Carbon Borders Drive the Industrial Decarbonization"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Munich, May 24, 2022


The carbon market has played an important role in accelerating Europe’s energy transition in the power sector. However, the ‘Fit for 55’ legislative package may shift the purpose and focus of the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) to spotlight industrial emission reductions: benchmarks are tighter, free allocations lower and new sectors, like road transport and buildings, may be added. The European Commission has also unveiled its carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM), which aims to protect EU industries from international competitors that do not pay a carbon price or equivalent. We will will look at the impact of the proposed reforms on industrials in particular and what we can expect if free allocations disappear.

Moderator:
Emma Coker
Emma Coker
Senior Associate, EU Carbon, BloombergNEF

Panelists:
Rob Barnett
Rob Barnett
Senior Analyst, Bloomberg Intelligence

Matt Gray (Remote)
Matt Gray (Remote)
Co-CEO and Co-founder, TransitionZero

Sanna O'Conner-Morberg
Sanna O'Conner-Morberg
Senior Science Manager, Carbon Direct

Liv Rathe (Remote)
Liv Rathe (Remote)
Director, Norsk Hydro

items.title: BNEF Summit: Voluntary Carbon Markets - Boom, Bust, Boom? What Comes Next?
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/703795568?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Summit: Voluntary Carbon Markets - Boom, Bust, Boom? What Comes Next?"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit New York, April 19-20, 2022

It's a moment of reckoning for the carbon offset market. Demand is on the rise and in record territory for the fifth consecutive year as the corporate race to net-zero accelerates. If demand continues to surge, BNEF forecasts that prices could increase fifty-fold by 2050. Suppliers are seeing these demand signals, ramping up offset creation in sectors ranging from direct air capture to reforestation. What are the market's shortfalls, even as it surges? What support from regulators and third-party initiatives can help supply meet demand? What kind of technologies can enlarge the market?

Amy Bann (Remote)
Head of Supply & Ecosystem, Xpansiv

Will Gardiner
CEO, Drax Group plc

Nathaniel Keohane
Senior Advisor, Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market

Kara Mangone
Global Head of Climate Strategy, Goldman Sachs

Moderator:

Kyle Harrison
Head of Sustainability Research, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Summit: Carbon Borders - A Tale of Two Models
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/706729968?app_id=122963" width="426" height="240" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Summit: Carbon Borders - A Tale of Two Models"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit New York, April 19-20, 2022

The Trump era brought tariffs to the forefront of policy makers' minds, just as the next target for decarbonization - heavy industry - began to be seriously considered.  Across the Atlantic, France has successfully advocated for an EU carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM), which is expected to be implemented in 2023.  The EU has also sought to build bridges with the Biden administration in creating an anti-dumping climate club that may conflict with the G7’s Industrial Decarbonization Agenda and even its own CBAM scheme.  The result of this low-level power and intellectual struggle will likely affect the cost of trade, particularly for goods deemed carbon-intensive and trade-exposed, and reshape international markets for sectors like steel and aluminum.  What are the commercial implications of these respective models? Which is likely to “win”?

David Kleimann
Senior Visiting Fellow, Bruegel

Michael Mehling (Remote)
Deputy Director, CEEPR, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Catrina Rorke
SVP, Research and Policy, Climate Leadership Council

Antoine Vagneur-Jones (Remote)
Head of Trade and Supply Chains, Energy Transitions, BloombergNEF


Moderator:


Julia Attwood
Head of Sustainable Materials, BloombergNEF

items.title: BNEF Summit: Offsets for the Transport Sector
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/675837614?app_id=122963" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Summit: Offsets for the Transport Sector"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit San Francisco, January 31st - February 1st 2022


Even the companies with the most aggressive sustainability targets in the transport sector will have residual emissions they cannot reduce. For many of these companies, carbon offsets are an essential transitional tool to address these residual emissions until more effective decarbonization options become available. For others, offsets are a fig leaf that distracts from instituting actual change. As the carbon offset market matures and works out some of its growing pains, transport companies in both of these buckets will need to confront a new reality. What are the current shortfalls of the offset market? How do changes in offset prices impact decarbonization strategies in the transport sector? What technologies are needed to further boost the market?

Chelsea Bryant
Managing Director, Radicle

Juan Moran
Global Customer Director, DHL

Stephanie Zhu
General Manager, Sustainability, Delta
 
Moderator:

Kyle Harrison
Head of Corporate Sustainability Research, BloombergNEF

items.title: Can We Offset Our Way to Net-Zero?: BNEF
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/673722066?app_id=122963" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="Can We Offset Our Way to Net-Zero?: BNEF"></iframe>

items.title: BNEF Talk: Carbon Market - Connecting the Dots
items.html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/652884735?app_id=122963" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen; picture-in-picture; clipboard-write" title="BNEF Talk: Carbon Market - Connecting the Dots"></iframe>
items.description:
BNEF Summit Shanghai, November 30-December 1, 2021


Bo Qin
Lead Analyst, European Carbon, BloombergNEF
